overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Identifying the Constant of Proportionality in Graphs
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students analyze real-world and mathematical situations, both proportional and non-proportional, represented on graphs and then identify the constant of proportionality when appropriate. Throughout the lesson, students interpret the meaning of points on graphs in terms of a proportional relationship, including the meaning of (1, y) and (0, 0).

overview_item_data_items: I can determine whether relationships represented in words, tables, equations, or graphs are proportional.
I can determine and interpret the constant of proportionality in various representations of proportional relationships.
I can interpret the meaning of proportional relationships and explain the significance of (0, 0) and (1, <math><mi>r</mi></math>).
The graph of a proportional relationship is linear and passes through the origin.
Each point on the graph that represents a proportional relationship has the same <math><mfrac><mi>y</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac></math> ratio.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students compare the characteristics of graphs to determine which graph is the odd one out.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Graphs of Two Constants of Proportionality
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students analyze a table of values and graphs to identify the constant of proportionality.
Students explain how to determine characteristics from a graph.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
